author: HCAndersen
text: THE well was deep, and therefore the rope had to be a long one; it was heavy work turning the handle when any one had to raise a bucketful of water over the edge of the well.

author: HCAndersen
text: Though the water was clear, the sun never looked down far enough into the well to mirror itself in the waters; but as far as its beams could reach, green things grew forth between the stones in the sides of the well.

author: HCAndersen
text: Down below dwelt a family of the Toad race.

author: HCAndersen
text: They had, in fact, come head-over-heels down the well, in the person of the old Mother-Toad, who was still alive.

author: HCAndersen
text: The green Frogs, who had been established there a long time, and swam about in the water, called them "well-guests."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the new-comers seemed determined to stay where they were, for they found it very agreeable living "in a dry place," as they called the wet stones.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Mother-Frog had once been a traveller.

author: HCAndersen
text: She happened to be in the water-bucket when it was drawn up, but the light became too strong for her, and she got a pain in her eyes.

author: HCAndersen
text: Fortunately she scrambled out of the bucket; but she fell into the water with a terrible flop, and had to lie sick for three days with pains in her back.

author: HCAndersen
text: She certainly had not much to tell of the things up above, but she knew this, and all the Frogs knew it, that the well was not all the world.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Mother-Toad might have told this and that, if she had chosen, but she never answered when they asked her anything, and so they left off asking.

author: HCAndersen
text: "She's thick, and fat and ugly," said the young green Frogs; "and her children will be just as ugly as she is."

author: HCAndersen
text: "That may be," retorted the mother-Toad, "but one of them has a jewel in his head, or else I have the jewel."

author: HCAndersen
text: The young frogs listened and stared; and as these words did not please them, they made grimaces and dived down under the water.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the little Toads kicked up their hind legs from mere pride, for each of them thought that he must have the jewel; and then they sat and held their heads quite still.

author: HCAndersen
text: But at length they asked what it was that made them so proud, and what kind of a thing a jewel might be.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, it is such a splendid and precious thing, that I cannot describe it," said the Mother-Toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's something which one carries about for one's own pleasure, and that makes other people angry.

author: HCAndersen
text: But don't ask me any questions, for I shan't answer you."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, I haven't got the jewel," said the smallest of the Toads; she was as ugly as a toad can be.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why should I have such a precious thing?

author: HCAndersen
text: And if it makes others angry, it can't give me any pleasure.

author: HCAndersen
text: No, I only wish I could get to the edge of the well, and look out; it must be beautiful up there."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You'd better stay where you are," said the old Mother-Toad, "for you know everything here, and you can tell what you have.

author: HCAndersen
text: Take care of the bucket, for it will crush you to death; and even if you get into it safely, you may fall out.

author: HCAndersen
text: And it's not every one who falls so cleverly as I did, and gets away with whole legs and whole bones.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Quack!" said the little Toad; and that's just as if one of us were to say, "Aha!"

author: HCAndersen
text: She had an immense desire to get to the edge of the well, and to look over; she felt such a longing for the green, up there; and the next morning, when it chanced that the bucket was being drawn up, filled with water, and stopped for a moment just in front of the stone on which the Toad sat, the little creature's heart moved within it, and our Toad jumped into the filled bucket, which presently was drawn to the top, and emptied out.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ugh, you beast!" said the farm laborer who emptied the bucket, when he saw the toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You're the ugliest thing I've seen for one while."

author: HCAndersen
text: And he made a kick with his wooden shoe at the toad, which just escaped being crushed by managing to scramble into the nettles which grew high by the well's brink.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here she saw stem by stem, but she looked up also; the sun shone through the leaves, which were quite transparent; and she felt as a person would feel who steps suddenly into a great forest, where the sun looks in between the branches and leaves.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's much nicer here than down in the well!

author: HCAndersen
text: I should like to stay here my whole life long!" said the little Toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: So she lay there for an hour, yes, for two hours.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wonder what is to be found up here?

author: HCAndersen
text: As I have come so far, I must try to go still farther."

author: HCAndersen
text: And so she crawled on as fast as she could crawl, and got out upon the highway, where the sun shone upon her, and the dust powdered her all over as she marched across the way.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I've got to a dry place. now, and no mistake," said the Toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's almost too much of a good thing here; it tickles one so."

author: HCAndersen
text: She came to the ditch; and forget-me-nots were growing there, and meadow-sweet; and a very little way off was a hedge of whitethorn, and elder bushes grew there, too, and bindweed with white flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: Gay colors were to be seen here, and a butterfly, too, was flitting by.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Toad thought it was a flower which had broken loose that it might look about better in the world, which was quite a natural thing to do.

author: HCAndersen
text: "If one could only make such a journey as that!" said the Toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Croak! how capital that would be."

author: HCAndersen
text: Eight days and eight nights she stayed by the well, and experienced no want of provisions.

author: HCAndersen
text: On the ninth day she thought, "Forward! onward!"

author: HCAndersen
text: But what could she find more charming and beautiful?

author: HCAndersen
text: Perhaps a little toad or a few green frogs.

author: HCAndersen
text: During the last night there had been a sound borne on the breeze, as if there were cousins in the neighborhood.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's a glorious thing to live! glorious to get out of the well, and to lie among the stinging-nettles, and to crawl along the dusty road.

author: HCAndersen
text: But onward, onward! that we may find frogs or a little toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: We can't do without that; nature alone is not enough for one."

author: HCAndersen
text: And so she went forward on her journey.

author: HCAndersen
text: She came out into the open field, to a great pond, round about which grew reeds; and she walked into it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It will be too damp for you here," said the Frogs; "but you are very welcome!

author: HCAndersen
text: Are you a he or a she?

author: HCAndersen
text: But it doesn't matter; you are equally welcome."

author: HCAndersen
text: And she was invited to the concert in the evening- the family concert; great enthusiasm and thin voices; we know the sort of thing.

author: HCAndersen
text: No refreshments were given, only there was plenty to drink, for the whole pond was free.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now I shall resume my journey," said the little Toad; for she always felt a longing for something better.

author: HCAndersen
text: She saw the stars shining, so large and so bright, and she saw the moon gleaming; and then she saw the sun rise, and mount higher and higher.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Perhaps after all, I am still in a well, only in a larger well.

author: HCAndersen
text: I must get higher yet; I feel a great restlessness and longing."

author: HCAndersen
text: And when the moon became round and full, the poor creature thought, "I wonder if that is the bucket which will be let down, and into which I must step to get higher up?

author: HCAndersen
text: Or is the sun the great bucket?

author: HCAndersen
text: How great it is! how bright it is!

author: HCAndersen
text: It can take up all.

author: HCAndersen
text: I must look out, that I may not miss the opportunity.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, how it seems to shine in my head!

author: HCAndersen
text: I don't think the jewel can shine brighter.

author: HCAndersen
text: But I haven't the jewel; not that I cry about that- no, I must go higher up, into splendor and joy!

author: HCAndersen
text: I feel so confident, and yet I am afraid.

author: HCAndersen
text: It's a difficult step to take, and yet it must be taken.

author: HCAndersen
text: Onward, therefore, straight onward!"

author: HCAndersen
text: She took a few steps, such as a crawling animal may take, and soon found herself on a road beside which people dwelt; but there were flower gardens as well as kitchen gardens.

author: HCAndersen
text: And she sat down to rest by a kitchen garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a number of different creatures there are that I never knew! and how beautiful and great the world is!

author: HCAndersen
text: But one must look round in it, and not stay in one spot."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then she hopped into the kitchen garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How green it is here! how beautiful it is here!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I know that," said the Caterpillar, on the leaf, "my leaf is the largest here.

author: HCAndersen
text: It hides half the world from me, but I don't care for the world."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Cluck, cluck!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And some fowls came.

author: HCAndersen
text: They tripped about in the cabbage garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Fowl who marched at the head of them had a long sight, and she spied the Caterpillar on the green leaf, and pecked at it, so that the Caterpillar fell on the ground, where it twisted and writhed.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Fowl looked at it first with one eye and then with the other, for she did not know what the end of this writhing would be.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It doesn't do that with a good will," thought the Fowl, and lifted up her head to peck at the Caterpillar.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Toad was so horrified at this, that she came crawling straight up towards the Fowl.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Aha, it has allies," quoth the Fowl.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Just look at the crawling thing!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And then the Fowl turned away.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I don't care for the little green morsel; it would only tickle my throat."

author: HCAndersen
text: The other fowls took the same view of it, and they all turned away together.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I writhed myself free," said the Caterpillar.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a good thing it is when one has presence of mind!

author: HCAndersen
text: But the hardest thing remains to be done, and that is to get on my leaf again.

author: HCAndersen
text: Where is it?"

author: HCAndersen
text: And the little Toad came up and expressed her sympathy.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was glad that in her ugliness she had frightened the fowls.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What do you mean by that?" cried the Caterpillar.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wriggled myself free from the Fowl.

author: HCAndersen
text: You are very disagreeable to look at.

author: HCAndersen
text: Cannot I be left in peace on my own property?

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I smell cabbage; now I am near my leaf.

author: HCAndersen
text: Nothing is so beautiful as property.

author: HCAndersen
text: But I must go higher up."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, higher up," said the little Toad; "higher-up!

author: HCAndersen
text: She feels just as I do; but she's not in a good humor to-day.

author: HCAndersen
text: That's because of the fright.

author: HCAndersen
text: We all want to go higher up."

author: HCAndersen
text: And she looked up as high as ever she could.

author: HCAndersen
text: The stork sat in his nest on the roof of the farm-house.

author: HCAndersen
text: He clapped with his beak, and the Mother-stork clapped with hers.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How high up they live!" thought the Toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: "If one could only get as high as that!"

author: HCAndersen
text: In the farm-house lived two young students; the one was a poet and the other a scientific searcher into the secrets of nature.

author: HCAndersen
text: The one sang and wrote joyously of everything that God had created, and how it was mirrored in his heart.

author: HCAndersen
text: He sang it out clearly, sweetly, richly, in well-sounding verses; while the other investigated created matter itself, and even cut it open where need was.

author: HCAndersen
text: He looked upon God's creation as a great sum in arithmetic- subtracted, multiplied, and tried to know it within and without, and to talk with understanding concerning it; and that was a very sensible thing; and he spoke joyously and cleverly of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were good, joyful men, those two, "There sits a good specimen of a toad," said the naturalist.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I must have that fellow in a bottle of spirits."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You have two of them already," replied the poet.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Let the thing sit there and enjoy its life."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But it's so wonderfully ugly," persisted the first.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, if we could find the jewel in its head," said the poet, "I too should be for cutting it open.'

author: HCAndersen
text: "A jewel!" cried the naturalist.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You seem to know a great deal about natural history."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But is there not something beautiful in the popular belief that just as the toad is the ugliest of animals, it should often carry the most precious jewel in its head?

author: HCAndersen
text: Is it not just the same thing with men?

author: HCAndersen
text: What a jewel that was that Aesop had, and still more, Socrates!"

author: HCAndersen
text: The Toad did not hear any more, nor did she understand half of what she had heard.

author: HCAndersen
text: The two friends walked on, and thus she escaped the fate of being bottled up in spirits.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Those two also were speaking of the jewel," said the Toad to herself.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a good thing that I have not got it!

author: HCAndersen
text: I might have been in a very disagreeable position."

author: HCAndersen
text: Now there was a clapping on the roof of the farm-house.

author: HCAndersen
text: Father-Stork was making a speech to his family, and his family was glancing down at the two young men in the kitchen garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Man is the most conceited creature!" said the Stork.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Listen how their jaws are wagging; and for all that they can't clap properly.

author: HCAndersen
text: They boast of their gifts of eloquence and their language!

author: HCAndersen
text: Yes, a fine language truly!

author: HCAndersen
text: Why, it changes in every day's journey we make.

author: HCAndersen
text: One of them doesn't understand another.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now, we can speak our language over the whole earth- up in the North and in Egypt.

author: HCAndersen
text: And then men are not able to fly, moreover.

author: HCAndersen
text: They rush along by means of an invention they call 'railway;' but they often break their necks over it.

author: HCAndersen
text: It makes my beak turn cold when I think of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The world could get on without men.

author: HCAndersen
text: We could do without them very well, so long as we only keep frogs and earth-worms."

author: HCAndersen
text: "That was a powerful speech," thought the little Toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a great man that is yonder! and how high he sits!

author: HCAndersen
text: Higher than ever I saw any one sit yet; and how he can swim!" she cried, as the Stork soared away through the air with outspread pinions.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the Mother-Stork began talking in the nest, and told about Egypt and the waters of the Nile, and the incomparable mud that was to be found in that strange land; and all this sounded new and very charming to the little Toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I must go to Egypt!" said she.

author: HCAndersen
text: "If the Stork or one of his young ones would only take me!

author: HCAndersen
text: I would oblige him in return.

author: HCAndersen
text: Yes, I shall get to Egypt, for I feel so happy!

author: HCAndersen
text: All the longing and all the pleasure that I feel is much better than having a jewel in one's head."

author: HCAndersen
text: And it was just she who had the jewel.

author: HCAndersen
text: That jewel was the continual striving and desire to go upward- ever upward.

author: HCAndersen
text: It gleamed in her head, gleamed in joy, beamed brightly in her longing.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then, suddenly, up came the Stork.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had seen the Toad in the grass, and stooped down and seized the little creature anything but gently.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Stork's beak pinched her, and the wind whistled; it was not exactly agreeable, but she was going upward- upward towards Egypt- and she knew it; and that was why her eyes gleamed, and a spark seemed to fly out of them.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Quunk!- ah!"

author: HCAndersen
text: The body was dead- the Toad was killed!

author: HCAndersen
text: But the spark that had shot forth from her eyes; what became of that?

author: HCAndersen
text: The sunbeam took it up; the sunbeam carried the jewel from the head of the toad.

author: HCAndersen
text: Whither?

author: HCAndersen
text: Ask not the naturalist; rather ask the poet.

author: HCAndersen
text: He will tell it thee under the guise of a fairy tale; and the Caterpillar on the cabbage, and the Stork family belong to the story.

author: HCAndersen
text: Think! the Caterpillar is changed, and turns into a beautiful butterfly; the Stork family flies over mountains and seas, to the distant Africa, and yet finds the shortest way home to the same country- to the same roof.

author: HCAndersen
text: Nay, that is almost too improbable; and yet it is true.

author: HCAndersen
text: You may ask the naturalist, he will confess it is so; and you know it yourself, for you have seen it.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the jewel in the head of the toad?

author: HCAndersen
text: Seek it in the sun; see it there if you can.

author: HCAndersen
text: The brightness is too dazzling there.

author: HCAndersen
text: We have not yet such eyes as can see into the glories which God has created, but we shall receive them by-and-by; and that will be the most beautiful story of all, and we shall all have our share in it.
